title: Rotational Inertia - comparing masses from graph

content.question: Two identical cylinders of mass <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math> are attached to a rotating apparatus at equal distances <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi></math> from the rotation axis, as shown in the figure. The rotational inertia <math alttext="l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi></math> of the apparatus-cylinders system is experimentally determined for multiple values of <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi></math>. The solid line in the graph shows the best-fit line for <math alttext="l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi></math> as a function of <math alttext="r squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math> for the identical cylinders with mass <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math>. The experiment is then repeated for two other identical cylinders of unknown mass. The dashed line in the graph shows the best-fit line for <math alttext="l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi></math> as a function of <math alttext="r squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math> for the cylinders of unknown mass. skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
